sense.name: Physically deliver a hard blow to; affect emotionally or mentally as if hitting; affect an abstract entity as if hitting.
sense.examples: The teacher smacked the student who had misbehaved. Oil prices have really smacked down the market. The sadness smacked me like a stiff wind. The car smacked the telephone pole.

sense.name: Have a distinctive or characteristic sensation, as perceived by the senses or intellect.
sense.examples: His speeches smacked of racism. This passage smacks of plagiarism. That dish simply smacks of nutmeg.

sense.name: Kiss lightly.
sense.examples: She smacked her grandson on the lips.

sense.name: Open and shut ones mouth repeatedly, as when eating, possibly producing a sound.
sense.examples: He smacked loudly during dinner. Don't smack so, Rupert!
